conclusion: The problem involves calculating the power of an electromagnetic railgun with given specifications: rail length (L = 0.5 m), rail spacing (d = 0.02 m), projectile mass (m = 0.02 kg), rail current (I = 10 A), and magnetic field strength (B = 1 T).
The image shows a schematic of parallel rails with a projectile between them and arrows indicating current flow.
The Lorentz force on the projectile is calculated as F = I × L × B = 10 A × 0.02 m × 1 T = 0.2 N.
The acceleration of the projectile is calculated using Newton's second law: a = F/m = 0.2 N / 0.02 kg = 10 m/s².
The final velocity of the projectile is calculated using the kinematic equation v² = v₀² + 2as, resulting in v = √10 m/s ≈ 3.16 m/s.
The kinetic energy of the projectile is calculated as E_k = 1/2 mv² = 1/2 × 0.02 kg × 10 m²/s² = 0.1 J.
The time it takes for the projectile to travel the length of the rails is calculated using s = v₀t + 1/2 at², resulting in t = √0.1 s ≈ 0.316 s.
The power is calculated as P = E_k / t = 0.1 J / 0.316 s ≈ 0.316 W.
The average velocity of the projectile is calculated as v_avg = v / 2 = 3.16 m/s / 2 ≈ 1.58 m/s.
The power is alternatively calculated as P = F × v_avg = 0.2 N × 1.58 m/s ≈ 0.316 W.
The final answer is determined: The power of the electromagnetic railgun when the projectile is launched is approximately 0.316 W.
